intro: Hippocentaurea inaperta, commonly known as the Alaskan sea holly, is a flowering plant native to the coastal regions of Alaska and northern Canada. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its showy, blue to violet flower heads. The plant has narrow, grass-like leaves and thrives in sandy or gravelly soils along the shoreline. It is adapted to harsh coastal conditions, including strong winds and salt spray, and blooms in late summer. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
